description.narrative: For With the funds, BIOS Quilmes will continue the Mala Sangre (Bad Blood) campaign, which is a movement to present the facts and scientific evidence of the residual effects of toxic pesticides on the human body. It aims to improve health and food security in cities like Mar del Plata and its suburb by promoting agricultural practices that do not rely on agrochemicals. Over the past 15 years, this movement has spread to cities throughout Argentina and has a massive media and public reaction. The state has started implementing stronger control over the use of agrochemicals and there is growing awareness of agroecological practices. Specifically, the group will map data collected from analyses on blood, urine, and commonly consumed vegetables to demonstrate the toxins' health risks and sphere of impact. It will promote a recovery buffer zone around the city where no agrochemicals will be used; promote food sovereignty and the right to information about one's food; develop the capacity of medical staff in identifying the symptoms associated with agrochemicals; collect epidemiological data on the effects of the toxins on human health; and promote agroecology as alternative to the chemical intensive model
